description: From Middle English frendly, freendly, frendely, frendlich, from Old English frēondlīċ, from Proto-Germanic *frijōndlīkaz, equivalent to friend +‎ -ly. Cognate with Saterland Frisian früntelk, fjuntelk (“friendly”), West Frisian freonlik (“friendly”), Dutch vriendelijk (“friendly”), German Low German fründelk, frünnelk (“friendly”), German freundlich (“friendly”).

adjectives.description: friendly (comparative friendlier or more friendly, superlative friendliest or most friendly)

entries.meaning: Generally warm, approachable and easy to relate with in character.
Having an easy or accepting relationship with something.
examples: the use of environmentally friendly packaging

entries.meaning: (in compounds) Compatible with, or not damaging to (the compounded noun).
examples: The cobbled streets aren't very bike-friendly.
Organic farms only use soil-friendly fertilisers.
Our sandwiches are made with dolphin-friendly tuna.

entries.meaning: Promoting the good of any person; favourable; propitious.
(usually military) Of or pertaining to friendlies (friendly noun sense 2, below). Also applied to other bipolar confrontations, such as team sports.
examples: The soldier was killed by friendly fire.

entries.meaning: (number theory) Being or relating to two or more natural numbers with a common abundancy.
(sports) A game which is of no consequence in terms of ranking, betting etc.
examples: This match is merely a friendly, so don't worry too much about it.

entries.meaning: A person or entity on the same side in a conflict.

description: From Middle English frendly, frendliche, from Old English frēondlīċe (“in a friendly manner”), equivalent to friend +‎ -ly.

adverbs.description: friendly (comparative more friendly, superlative most friendly)

entries.meaning: (archaic) In a friendly manner, like a friend.
